 Primaries and their twin, caucuses, are a game of musical chairs. Instead of playing music, candidates flesh out their positions state by state. Those that sing a good tune to the listeners are assured a chair --which translates to money -- when the voting in each state occurs. The chairs continue to dwindle down to one, which will be given to the presumptive nominee. A national convention will then be held to make it official. He alone will appear on the national ballot as the Democratic choice for president (Dennis Kucinch, who is still running as a Democrat despite having no chair to sit in will not be on the ballot). This process winnows candidates down to one per party.The Republicans did not go through the process this election cycle only because no one wanted to challenge the sitting president.
